p: Here, we addressed the possible evolution of defense traits and tolerance to A. hygrophila, and the impact of shade on possible evolution of herbivory tolerance in A. philoxeroides. We conducted a common garden experiment in the introduced range of A. philoxeroides using ten invasive (USA) and ten native (Argentina) populations at two levels of light availability and in the presence or absence of a specialist insect A. hygrophila. Plant biomass (total biomass and storage biomass), two allocation traits (root/shoot ratio and branch intensity, branches biomass/main stem biomass) and two functional traits (specific stem length and specific leaf area) were measured. These traits are all potentially plastic in response to herbivory and shade.
